body: To tell a powerful story you need to be able undertake the majority - if not all - of the stages of data storytelling. Success will depend on understanding the time requirement of each stage in the process.
title: The four step process

_aboutPage.aboutCredit: This work "The four step process", adapted from "The four step process" by Open Data Institute, used under CC-BY 4.0.

body: Organising data ready for it to be processed is an essential skills for anyone working with data. In this module we explore how to design and implement a structure for a dataset that can be easily understood by others.
title: Organising data

_aboutPage.aboutCredit: This work "Organising data", adapted from "Organising data" by Open Data Institute, used under CC-BY 4.0.

_skills.outcome: Identify good and bad spreadsheet layouts
Create good column titles for a spreadsheet
Use header rows and freeze functions in spreadsheets
Use different data types in a spreadsheet

body: Schemas play a key role in enabling the wide, automated re-use of data. This module looks at the role of and importance of schemas in assisting reusability and quality of data.
title: Choosing and designing schemas

body: Data containing errors leads to stories containing errors. Before any analysis can take place, you need to be able to identify and remove them from data. This module looks at common errors and useful tools to remove them.
title: Cleaning data

_skills.outcome: Explain how and why data needs to be cleaned
Recognise a number of errors in data

body:
The format of an open dataset is the way the data is structured and made available for humans and machines.

Choosing the right format enables simpler management and reuse of the data. To maximise reuse of the data, it may be necessary for a publisher to use a number of formats and structures available across different platforms that suit a user’s needs.
title: Data formats and structures

_aboutPage.aboutCredit: This work "Choosing the right format for open data", is a derivative of "Choosing the right format for open data" by European Commission, used under CC-BY-SA 4.0.

_skills.outcome: Identify characteristics of different data formats
List criteria for choosing the right data format

body: Open data and open standards are very closely related, both in definition and application. This module examines what open standards are and why they are important for open data.
title: Open data and open standards

body: Describing and annotating datasets provides an opportunity for data to be better understood across borders and sectors. Adding detail can help with discovery, access, retrieval, organisation and understanding. In this module, we will look at what data annotation is and how it can be applied to different types of data.
title: Annotating and describing data
